> http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/cookstour/cookstour.htm 
> <http://junit.sourceforge.net/doc/cookstour/cookstour.htm>

> I see that the asserts do throw exceptions ...but that exception is
> already caught in the TestResult class in the framework. So if I wrap
> the assert in my test case....I don't think I'll be catching that
> exception. Who knows, maybe I can catch it....and then rethrow it? I
> will try that.
> 
> Yes...reporting. I was trying to massage the results.xml Junit output
> file with .xsl...and had some success...but not total success...I want
> to try writing my own XML output as the tests run. Maybe this is a
> bad idea...but the .xsl approach wasn't so good.
> 
> I was also reading JUnit Recipes, and I guess I could write my own
> JUnit Results Formatter (Junit recipes, 7.6), but this might be biting
> off more than I want to chew right now.

What if you introduce a BaseTestCase (I forget the recipe number) then 
override runTest() to catch the exception, log your information, then 
rethrow it? That might give you a path of less resistance, but I imagine 
that, in due time, you'll want to just do recipe 7.6.
